items.title: Self-consistent layer-projected scissors operator for band structures of two-dimensional van der Waals materials with large unit cells

items.summary: The authors present here a fast and accurate method to compute quasiparticle band structures of van der Waals heterostructures. A self-consistent layer-projected scissors (LAPS) operator corrects intralayer and interlayer self-energy effects, capturing charge redistribution and hybridization while avoiding supercell artifacts. The method achieves excellent agreement with state-of-the-art many-body calculations at a fraction of the cost, enabling realistic simulations of multilayer systems and moiré heterostructures with tens of thousands of atoms. Applications to MoS 2 films, MoS 2 /WS 2 bilayers, and MoSe 2 /WS 2 moiré structures showcase its predictive power for complex 2D materials. [Phys. Rev. B 112, 115128] Published Fri Sep 12, 2025

items.summary: Ising machines efficiently solve binary optimization problems but face scalability limits in nonbinary tasks such as graph coloring due to their bistable dynamics. This work overcomes Ising machine scalability limits by introducing a Potts machine verified with novel experimental data from parametri… [Phys. Rev. Applied 24, 034034] Published Fri Sep 12, 2025

items.summary: The ability to tune quantum tunneling is key for achieving selectivity in manipulation of individual particles in quantum technology applications. In this work we count electron escape events out of a time-dependent confinement potential, realized as a dynamic quantum dot in a GaAs/AlGaAs heterostru… [Phys. Rev. Applied] Published Fri Sep 12, 2025

Applied] Published Fri Sep 12, 2025

With the Andreev bound state being confined to the nanoscale weak link, it couples to a circuit-QED architecture via the state-dep… [Phys. Rev. Applied] Published Fri Sep 12, 2025

authors: Hamza Jnane and Simon C. Benjamin
items.summary: Electron spins in semiconductor devices are highly promising building blocks for quantum processors (QPs). Commercial semiconductor foundries can create QPs using the same processes employed for conventional chips, once the QP design is suitably specified. There is a vast accessible design space; to… [Phys. Rev. Applied] Published Fri Sep 12, 2025

items.title: Cryogenic temperature dependence and hysteresis of surface-trap-induced gate leakage in GaN high-electron-mobility transistors
authors: Ching-Yang Pan, Shi-Kai Lin, Yu-An Chen, and Pei-hsun Jiang
items.summary: This work provides a detailed mapping of various mechanisms of surface-trap-induced gate leakage in GaN HEMTs across a temperature range from room to cryogenic levels. Two-dimensional variable-range hopping is observed at small gate bias. Under higher reverse gate bias, the leakage is dominated by t… [Phys. Rev. Applied] Published Fri Sep 12, 2025

items.title: Optimization via quantum preconditioning
authors: Maxime Dupont, Tina Oberoi, and Bhuvanesh Sundar
items.summary: State-of-the-art classical optimization solvers set a high bar for quantum computers to deliver utility in this domain. Here, we introduce a quantum preconditioning approach based on the quantum approximate optimization algorithm. It transforms the input problem into a more suitable form for a solve… [Phys. Rev. Applied] Published Fri Sep 12, 2025

items.summary: Regulating carrier transport at semiconductor interfaces using light is essential for optimizing optoelectronic devices. Recent advancements in ultrafast scanning electron microscopy and finite element methods have provided deeper insights into photo-induced ballistic carrier dynamics in silicon p-n… [Phys. Rev. Applied] Published Fri Sep 12, 2025

items.title: Drainage front width in a three-dimensional random porous medium under gravitational and capillary effects
authors: Paula Reis and Knut Jørgen Måløy
items.summary: A theoretical approach to estimating stable drainage front widths in three-dimensional (3D) random porous media under gravitational and capillary effects is presented here. Based on the frontier of the infinite cluster in gradient percolation, we propose an expression for the 3D front width dependen… [Phys. Rev. Research 7, 033244] Published Fri Sep 12, 2025

items.title: Quantum estimation of Chernoff bound and Hoeffding bound
authors: Honglin Chen, Jicun Li, Wei Xie, and Xiang-Yang Li
items.summary: Determining the closeness of two quantum states with minimal error probability is a central problem in quantum information theory. The optimal exponents characterizing the error probability in the symmetric and asymmetric settings are given by the quantum Chernoff bound (QCB) and the quantum Hoeffdi… [Phys. Rev. Research 7, 033245] Published Fri Sep 12, 2025

items.title: Abelian spectral topology of multifold exceptional points
items.summary: The advent of non-Hermitian physics has enriched the plethora of topological phases to include phenomena without Hermitian counterparts. Despite being among the most well-studied uniquely non-Hermitian features, the topological properties of multifold exceptional points, $n$-fold spectral degeneraci… [Phys. Rev. Research 7, 033246] Published Fri Sep 12, 2025

authors: Omprakash Chandra, Gopikrishnan Muraleedharan, and Gavin K. Brennen

However, unlike the surface code that has simple, geometrically local, stabilizer checks, qLDPC cod… [Phys. Rev. Research 7, 033247] Published Fri Sep 12, 2025

items.title: Nonlinear spectroscopy of cavity polaritons
authors: Anqi Li, Upendra Harbola, and Michael Galperin
items.summary: Confinement of molecules within a cavity leads to a strong coupling between light and matter degrees of freedom, merging the two into a quasiparticle known as a polariton. Theoretical treatments of molecular polaritons generally utilize either exact diagonalization of the interacting molecule-cavity… [Phys. Rev. Research 7, 033248] Published Fri Sep 12, 2025

items.title: Crisis-induced intermittency in reservoir computing
authors: Tempei Kabayama, Motomasa Komuro, Yasuo Kuniyoshi, Kazuyuki Aihara, and Kohei Nakajima
items.summary: This study analyzes symmetric models to show that adjusting a global parameter in random neural networks—which develop multistability through reservoir computing—induces a crisis with intermittency. [Phys. Rev. Research 7, L032058] Published Fri Sep 12, 2025

items.title: Decoding strong-field ionization of ${\mathrm{H}}_{2}$ via photoelectron momentum torus
authors: Daimu Ikeya, Hikaru Fujise, Minami Takahashi, Kyoichiro Yasui, Akitaka Matsuda, Mizuho Fushitani, Hirokazu Matsui, Hiroka Hasegawa, Oleg I. Tolstikhin, Toru Morishita, and Akiyoshi Hishikawa
items.summary: A quantitative decoding of strong-field ionization of H 2 from its photoelectron momentum torus is demonstrated, providing a precise and robust framework for extracting molecular ionization potentials and laser field parameters directly from the photoelectron momentum distribution. items.title: How to help refugees thrive: have local families host them
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02873-4 Ukrainian refugees who moved into German households report greater social integration than those who lived in other settings.

items.title: Meet Europe’s first exascale supercomputer — can it compete in the global AI race?
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02981-1 JUPITER, the European Union’s new exascale supercomputer, is 100% powered by renewable energy. What will researchers use it for?

items.title: These nations are wooing PhD students amid US funding uncertainties
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02416-x Pauses to some US graduate programmes have led universities in several countries to launch initiatives to entice would-be PhD students.

items.title: LIGO is 10 years old: black-hole breakthroughs will ‘only get better’
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02941-9 A decade after the pair of observatories first detected gravitational waves, researchers are drawing up ambitious plans for its successors.

items.title: Maintenance
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02777-3 A difficult thing to fix.

items.title: Why we launched Denmark’s second Young Academy (and what’s different about it)
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02520-y YATSI aims to represent scientists based in academia and in industry, and to build bridges between the two sectors.

items.title: RFK Jr’s vaccine advisers will soon review four shots: what’s at stake
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02914-y Restrictions to children's vaccine access are a likely outcome, infectious-disease specialists tell Nature.

items.title: Boron at the boundaries
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03041-1 Boron at the boundaries

items.title: In plain sight
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03021-5 In plain sight

items.title: Serendipitous signal
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03052-y The first direct observation of gravitational waves occurred on 14 September 2015. We look back at ten years of gravitational wave science.

items.title: Precision without parity
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03018-0 Metrology has long been defined by its pursuit of reproducibility, accuracy and traceability. Yet, when it comes to the representation of women and other marginalized communities, precision has not been matched by parity, finds Solmaz Nadiri.

items.title: Parallelized telecom quantum networking with an ytterbium-171 atom array
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03022-4 Most atom-based quantum networks emit photons at non-telecom wavelengths, requiring lossy conversion for long-distance links. A scalable approach for generating direct entanglement between atoms and telecom-band photons has now been demonstrated.

items.title: Author Correction: Causal disentanglement for single-cell representations and controllable counterfactual generation
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63728-0 Author Correction: Causal disentanglement for single-cell representations and controllable counterfactual generation

items.title: Asymmetric coordination enhances the synergy of Pt species dual active sites for efficient photocatalytic H<sub>2</sub> evolution
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63637-2 Photocatalytic water splitting is hindered by inefficient cooperation between catalytic sites. Here, the authors report that asymmetric Pt coordination enables a strong synergy between single-atom sites and nanoparticles, delivering efficient photocatalytic hydrogen production.

items.title: Heterogeneous, temporally consistent, and plastic brain development after preterm birth
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63967-1 This study reveals that brain aberrations after preterm birth are highly individual yet shaped by early injury and social environment, influencing long-term cognitive outcomes.

items.title: Matrix directs trophoblast differentiation in a bioprinted organoid model of early placental development
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-62996-0 The placenta plays vital roles in supporting fetal development. Here, Richards et al. develop a high-throughput bioprinted trophoblast organoid model to recapitulate the microenvironment of the early placenta, enabling investigation of placenta development and evaluation of therapeutics for placenta dysfunction disorders.

items.title: Meltwater ponding has an underestimated radiative effect on the surface of the Greenland Ice Sheet
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-62503-5 Meltwater ponding reduces Greenland Ice Sheet albedo, but this process is not included in models. This study uses drone imagery to show that small streams and ponds, often missed by satellites, considerably increase the energy available for melt.

items.title: The reference genome of the human diploid cell line RPE-1
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-62428-z The authors present a diploid reference-quality genome assembly of the widely used cell line RPE-1, revealing heightened variation between haplotypes and other human genomes at centromeres. The availability of a reference genome matching the cell line under study promises a new era of high-precision haplotype-resolved functional genomics.

items.title: Temporal control of human DNA replication licensing by CDK4/6-RB signalling and chemical genetics
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63669-8 Cells must coordinate cell division with genome replication. Here, the authors combine rapid protein depletion, clinical CDK4/6 inhibitors, and genome-wide EdU sequencing to reveal that the CDK4/6-RB axis ensures timely loading of DNA replication factors in G1 phase in human cells.

items.title: Tastes and retronasal odours evoke a shared flavour-specific neural code in the human insula
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63803-6 Food aromas stimulate smell receptors in the nose but are often mistaken for tastes. This study shows that aromas induce taste-like patterns in the insular cortex. These results explain the illusion and the prominent role of odours in food reward.
